title: Victor de Fay de La Tour-Maubourg
text:
Marie-Victor-Nicolas de Faÿ, Marquis de La Tour-Maubourg (22 May 1768 – 11 November 1850) was a French <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a> commander under <a href="Kingdom%20of%20France">France</a>'s <a href="Ancien%20R%C3%A9gime">Ancien Régime</a> before rising to prominence during the <a href="First%20French%20Empire">First French Empire</a>.
Under the <a href="Bourbon%20Restoration%20in%20France">Restoration</a>, he served as a <a href="diplomat">diplomat</a> and <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">parliament</a>arian; after being created a <a href="Marquis">Marquis</a>, he was also briefly in <a href="Government%20of%20France">government</a> as <a href="Minister%20of%20Defence%20%28France%29">Minister of War</a> between 1819 and 1821.
Early years and family.
Of aristocratic descent, his father was Claude-Florimond de Faÿ, <a href="Count">comte</a> de <a href="Arlanc">Coisse</a> (1712–1790) and his mother was Marie-Françoise (1712–1793), daughter of Nicolas de Vachon, .
De Faÿ joined the <a href="French%20Army">French Army</a> as a "<a href="Second%20lieutenant">Sous-lieutenant</a>" in the <a href="Garde%20du%20Corps%20%28France%29">Gardes du Corps</a>.
He was promoted <a href="Colonel">Colonel</a> of the <a href="1st-11th%20Cuirassier%20Regiment">3rd Chasseurs-à-Cheval Regiment</a>, 5 February 1792, before serving at <a href="Philippeville">Philippeville</a>, <a href="Verton">Grisvelle</a> and <a href="Maubeuge">Maubeuge</a>.
In August 1792, he was captured by the <a href="Army%20of%20the%20Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Austrians</a> at <a href="Rochefort%2C%20Belgium">Rochefort</a>, being taken prisoner with <a href="Gilbert%20du%20Motier%2C%20marquis%20de%20Lafayette">Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette</a>. However, his release was quickly negotiated while his brother was eventually released only after the Treaty of <a href="Campo-Formio">Campo-Formio</a> in 1797.
De Faÿ then became an "<a href="%C3%A9migr%C3%A9">émigré</a>" living in <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> and <a href="Brussels">Brussels</a>. In 1804 at <a href="Utrecht">Utrecht</a>, Colonel de Faÿ married Pétronille van Rijssel ("later <a href="style%20%28manner%20of%20address%29">styled</a>" <a href="marchioness">marquise</a> de La Tour-Maubourg), who predeceased him on 17 July 1844.
His elder brother, <a href="Charles%20C%C3%A9sar%20de%20Fay%20de%20La%20Tour-Maubourg">Charles César de Fay de La Tour-Maubourg</a> was also a French Army general, and his younger brother, <a href="Juste-Charles%20de%20la%20Tour-Maubourg">Juste-Charles de la Tour-Maubourg</a> was married to Anastasie de La Fayette (1777–1863).
Egypt.
At the end of 1799 de Faÿ returned to France and was posted to <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> by the <a href="First%20Consul">First Consul</a>. There he served as "<a href="Aide-de-Camp">Aide-de-Camp</a>" to General <a href="Jean%20Baptiste%20Kl%C3%A9ber">Jean Baptiste Kléber</a>, who both received head wounds at <a href="Battle%20of%20Alexandria%20%281801%29">Alexandria</a> caused by an incendiary-<a href="Shell%20%28projectile%29">device</a>, 13 March 1801. After Kléber's assassination he was appointed AdC to General <a href="Jacques-Francois%20Menou">Jacques-Francois Menou</a>.
Campaigns of 1805–1807.
De Faÿ was present at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Austerlitz">Battle of Austerlitz</a> and served in Germany under General <a href="%C3%89douard%20Jean%20Baptiste%20Milhaud">Édouard Jean Baptiste Milhaud</a>, commanding the <a href="Chasseurs%20%C3%A0%20Cheval%20de%20la%20Garde%20Imp%C3%A9riale">22nd Chasseurs-à-Cheval Regiment</a>, part of Marshal <a href="Joachim%20Murat">Joachim Murat</a>'s <a href="Reserve%20Cavalry%20Corps%20%28Grande%20Arm%C3%A9e%29">Reserve Cavalry Corps</a>; shortly afterwards, on <a href="Christmas%20Eve">24 December</a> 1805, he was appointed <a href="Brigadier-General">Brigadier-General</a>.
He then served in the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Fourth%20Coalition">War of the Fourth Coalition</a> during the Prussia and Poland campaigns, and fought at <a href="Battle%20of%20Jena-Auerstedt">Jena</a>. He was then seconded to the <a href="II%20Cavalry%20Corps%20%28Grande%20Arm%C3%A9e%29">3rd Dragoon Division</a> under 's command. He was promoted "<a href="G%C3%A9n%C3%A9ral%20de%20division">Général de division</a>" on 14 May 1807 and commanded the <a href="Royal%20Horse%20Guards">1st Dragoon Division</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Heilsberg">Battle of Heilsberg</a>; he suffered battle wounds at <a href="Battle%20of%20Friedland">Friedland</a>, where his <a href="Division%20%28military%29">division</a> was supporting the right flank of <a href="Marshal%20Victor">Marshal Victor</a>'s <a href="I%20Corps%20%28Grande%20Arm%C3%A9e%29">I Corps</a>.
Spain and Russia.
In 1808, de Faÿ commanded the cavalry of the <a href="Arm%C3%A9e%20du%20Midi">Armée du Midi</a> under Marshals <a href="Jean-Baptiste%20Bessi%C3%A8res">Jean-Baptiste Bessières</a>, <a href="Claude%20Victor">Claude Victor</a> and <a href="Jean%20de%20Dieu%20Soult">Jean de Dieu Soult</a> in the Spanish <a href="Peninsular%20War">Peninsular War</a>. He served at the Fall of Madrid, and at the battles of <a href="Battle%20of%20Ucl%C3%A9s%20%281809%29">Uclés</a>, <a href="Cuenca%2C%20Spain">Cuenca</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Medell%C3%ADn">Medellín</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Talavera">Talavera</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Ocana">Ocana</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Gebora">Gebora</a>, <a href="Alburquerque%2C%20Badajoz">Albuquerque</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Albuera">Albuera</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Usagre">Usagre</a>, <a href="Elvas%20Municipality">Elvas</a>, being wounded at <a href="Battle%20of%20Villafranca%20%281809%29">Villafranca</a>; one of his dispatches was intercepted and deciphered by the British.
In May 1808, de Faÿ was created a <a href="Baron%20de%20l%27Empire">Baron de l'Empire</a> in addition to his ancient family titles: they were <a href="Count">Count</a>s of Coisse in <a href="kingdom%20of%20France">France</a>.
Baron de Faÿ de La Tour-Maubourg was appointed <a href="General%20officer">General commanding</a> the <a href="IV%20Cavalry%20Corps%20%28Grande%20Arm%C3%A9e%29">IV Cavalry Corps</a> for <a href="French%20invasion%20of%20Russia">Napoleon's March on Moscow</a>. He was wounded at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Borodino">Battle of Borodino</a>, was noted for his distinguished and gallant service at <a href="Mozhaysk">Mozhaysk</a> leading France's <a href="Sacred%20Squadron%20%28France%29">Sacred Squadron</a>, and having survived the retreat, later commanded the <a href="I%20Cavalry%20Corps%20%28Grande%20Arm%C3%A9e%29">I Cavalry Corps</a> at <a href="Battle%20of%20Bautzen%20%281813%29">Bautzen</a>, <a href="Dzier%C5%BConi%C3%B3w">Reichenbach</a> <a href="Z%C5%82otoryja">Goldberg</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20L%C3%BCtzen%20%281813%29">Lutzen</a>, and <a href="Battle%20of%20Dresden">Dresden</a>.
At <a href="Markkleeberg">Wachau</a>, during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Leipzig">Battle of Leipzig</a>, Baron de Faÿ's 1st Cavalry Corps along with <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois%20%C3%89tienne%20de%20Kellermann">François Étienne de Kellermann</a>'s <a href="III%20Cavalry%20Corps%20%28Grande%20Arm%C3%A9e%29">3rd Cavalry Corps</a> and the <a href="Dragons%20de%20la%20Garde%20Imp%C3%A9riale">Dragoon Guards</a> charged the center of <a href="Eugen%20Duke%20of%20W%C3%BCrttemberg%20%281788%E2%80%931857%29">Eugen von Württemberg</a>'s line; the Duke of Württemberg's Imperial Russian Guards then counter-attacked, stabilizing their position.
He lost a leg from the knee, famously stating when his valet wept upon sight of his injury: "What are you crying about, man, you have one less boot to polish".
The amputation was administered by the celebrated <a href="Military%20medicine">French Army surgeon</a>, <a href="Dominique%20Jean%20Larrey">Baron Dominique-Jean Larrey</a>, who noted in his memoirs: "he ["de Faÿ"] was hit by a small caliber ball which smashed his right knee to pieces, a serious wound which required amputation below the thigh, requested by the casualty himself: I immediately practised it under enemy fire. It was completed in less than three minutes".
Restoration of the Monarchy.
With the <a href="Bourbon%20Restoration%20in%20France">restoration of the Bourbons</a> he swore allegiance to <a href="Louis%20XVIII%20of%20France">Louis XVIII</a> and his loyalty to the king during the <a href="Hundred%20Days">Hundred Days</a> was rewarded by being created a "<a href="Pair%20de%20France">Pair de France</a>", 1814 and advanced as <a href="Marquis">Marquis</a> in 1817.
De Faÿ served in several diplomatic posts, including appointment as <a href="List%20of%20Ambassadors%20of%20France%20to%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Ambassador to London</a> in 1819, where he corresponded with <a href="Robert%20Stewart%2C%20Viscount%20Castlereagh">Lord Castlereagh</a>. He was briefly <a href="Minister%20of%20Defence%20%28France%29">Minister of War</a> (November 1819 – December 1821), and Governor of <a href="Les%20Invalides">Les Invalides</a> (December 1821), as well as sitting on the Tribunal which sentenced the French Marshal <a href="Michel%20Ney">Prince Michel Ney</a> to death.
In August 1831, he commenced negotiations with the Belgians (his wife's family was Flemish) regarding frontier forts, before the British intervened.
